steps.notes: Mine mare regolith from surface
Screen and separate size fractions
Crush and grind coarse regolith to powder
Extract oxygen and produce metal byproduct via MRE

recipe_def.assumptions: Co-product metal alloy from MRE; refining not modeled.

steps.notes: Hot roll steel ingot to produce raw steel plate; includes heating, rolling, and final sizing

recipe_def.assumptions: Chain from steel ingot to raw steel plate via hot rolling and final sizing; final product is raw stock for fabrication.
recipe_def.notes: Local production recipe to replace import stub for steel_plate_raw.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for steel plate raw (local)

steps.notes: Hot roll steel ingot into bar or billet shapes

recipe_def.assumptions: Semi-finished steel product from hot rolling of ingots. Standard stock sizes for machining and forging feedstock.
recipe_def.notes: Production of steel bar and billet stock from ingots. Processing time ~1.5 hours per kg. ~5% loss to scale and trim.

steps.notes: Convert ingot into 3mm steel sheet

recipe_def.assumptions: Assumes input ingot is steel and thickness target is 3mm.
recipe_def.notes: Initial production recipe for steel sheet (3mm) from steel ingot.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for steel sheet 3mm

steps.notes: Hall-Héroult electrolysis at ~960°C. Very energy-intensive (15 kWh/kg)

inputs.notes: Aluminum oxide extracted from highland regolith
Flux to lower melting point (~90% recycled)

recipe_def.assumptions:
Hall-Héroult process produces aluminum suitable for structural applications.
Cryolite flux is 90% recyclable. Carbon anode consumption rate is 0.5 kg per kg aluminum.
Energy requirement: 15 kWh/kg is realistic for electrolytic aluminum production.
recipe_def.notes:
Aluminum alloy ingot production via Hall-Héroult electrolysis from alumina.

This is the standard industrial process for primary aluminum production.
Extremely energy-intensive (15 kWh/kg output) but enables local aluminum
production from lunar highland regolith.

Process chain from regolith:
1. Highland regolith (100 kg) → alumina extraction → 12 kg alumina
2. Alumina (2 kg) → Hall-Héroult smelting → 1 kg aluminum ingot
3. Therefore: ~17 kg regolith → 1 kg aluminum ingot

Replaces placeholder recipe that incorrectly used generic melting/casting.
Placeholder recipe: produces aluminum_wire via the existing wire_drawing_aluminum_v0 process (ingot -> wire + scrap).
Recipe to manufacture silicon_powder_v0 via grinding silicon metal v0.
Base recipe linking the silicone_precursor_synthesis_v0 process to the silicone_precursor product.
recipe_def.name: Silicone precursor synthesis recipe v0

steps.notes: Synthesize silicone polymer from precursor materials

recipe_def.notes: Base recipe linking the silicone_polymer_synthesis_v0 process to the silicone_polymer product.
Link coil insulation material to production process coil_insulation_production_v0 to resolve no_recipe gap.

recipe_def.assumptions: Cast small races; machine and finish to bearing dimensions; finishing not modeled yet.
recipe_def.notes: Coarse local route for bearing_set_small; refine with grinding/finishing in a future update.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for bearing_set_small (v0)

steps.notes: Fabricate and weld heavy steel frame structure for power hammer
Machine mounting surfaces, guide rails, and anvil mounting points
Verify frame alignment and structural integrity

recipe_def.assumptions: Heavy steel frame for power hammer forging operations. Designed to withstand repeated impact loads.
recipe_def.notes: Power hammer frame construction. 120 kg frame provides rigid structure for forging. Total fabrication time ~13 hours.

steps.notes: Cast steel hammer head blank (approx 45 kg raw for 40 kg finished)
Machine hammer face, mounting hole, and guide surfaces
Heat treat hammer head for hardness and impact resistance
Grind striking face flat and smooth
Verify hardness, dimensions, and surface finish

recipe_def.assumptions: Heavy steel hammer head for power hammer operations. Heat-treated for impact resistance and wear resistance.
recipe_def.notes: Hammer head/ram for small power hammer forging operations. 40 kg mass provides impact energy for metalworking. Total fabrication time ~10-11 hours.

steps.notes: Cast heavy steel anvil block (approx 90 kg raw for 80 kg finished)
Machine anvil face flat and mounting surfaces
Heat treat anvil for hardness and impact resistance
Grind anvil face smooth and flat
Verify hardness, flatness, and surface finish

recipe_def.assumptions: Heavy steel anvil block for forging and pressing operations. Heat-treated for hardness and durability under repeated impact.
recipe_def.notes: Anvil block fabrication for power hammer. 80 kg mass provides stable working surface. Total fabrication time ~12-13 hours.

steps.notes: Cast motor housing and rotor shaft for power hammer drive
Machine rotor shaft, bearing journals, and mounting interfaces
Wind stator coils for motor windings
Assemble motor components, install bearings, and wire connections
Test motor operation and verify power output

recipe_def.assumptions: Electric drive motor for power hammer operations. Provides impact energy for forging and shaping operations.
recipe_def.notes: Drive motor for power hammer. 30 kg motor provides impact power for metalworking. Total fabrication time ~8-9 hours.
